Create a fully responsive, modern AI chatbot website named ‚ÄúOursGPT‚Äù, inspired by ChatGPT.

üß† Core Features

AI-powered chat interface similar to ChatGPT

Clean chat bubbles (user on right, AI on left)

Smooth typing animation for AI responses

Message history stored in browser (local storage)

New chat / clear chat button

Light & Dark mode toggle

üñºÔ∏è Image Understanding & Image Generation

Allow users to upload images and ask questions about them

AI should analyze images and respond accurately

Include a separate ‚ÄúImage Generator‚Äù tab

Users can enter prompts to generate high-quality AI images

Options: realistic, anime, cinematic, 3D, illustration

üé® UI / UX Design

Modern minimal design (like ChatGPT)

Soft gradients, rounded corners, smooth animations

Mobile-first responsive layout

Sidebar with:

New Chat

Image Generator

History

Settings

‚öôÔ∏è Tech Stack

Frontend: HTML, CSS, JavaScript (or React if possible)

Backend-ready structure (API-based)

Clean, well-commented code

Easy to deploy on free hosting (GitHub Pages / Vercel / Netlify)

üåê Pages

Home (Chat Interface)

Image Generator

About OursGPT

Privacy Policy

üöÄ Performance & Quality

Fast loading

SEO optimized

Accessible design

Professional production-ready output

The website should look premium, futuristic, and trustworthy‚Äîjust like a real AI product.

**Crafting the Interface**

I'm currently focused on the user interface for OursGPT, drawing inspiration from ChatGPT. I'm prioritizing a clean chat layout with user messages on the right and AI responses on the left. The plan is to include a typing animation for a more dynamic and engaging feel, and to store message history locally for easy access and continuation of conversations. I'm also planning "New Chat" and "Clear Chat" functionalities to add flexibility.


**Designing Advanced Features**

I've been expanding on the interface by adding a light/dark mode toggle for user preference. I'm also including image understanding capabilities, allowing users to upload images and ask questions. A dedicated image generation tab is also in development, with various style options like realistic, anime, and cinematic. The UI will be minimalist, mobile-first, and responsive. I've chosen a hash router, with pages for Home, Image Generator, About, and Privacy. The tech stack will be React (TypeScript), Tailwind CSS, and the Gemini API, leveraging `gemini-3-flash-preview` for the chat and image analysis, while `gemini-2.5-flash-image` will be used for image generation. Finally, the app will consist of components such as Layout, App, and index.

**Building the Architecture**

I'm now deep in the codebase, with a clear component breakdown. The `ChatView` and `ImageGeneratorView` are taking shape, while `MessageBubble` handles the chat bubbles and `Sidebar` provides navigation. `gemini.ts` encapsulates the Gemini API interactions, and I'm utilizing `useLocalStorage.ts` for data persistence. For the theme, Tailwind's `dark:` classes, and local storage will manage user preference. I'm focusing on the chat message format (`role` and `content`), image upload mechanism, and animation strategy. I've opted for simplified Tailwind transitions over Framer Motion, for a more streamlined development process.


**Defining Component Hierarchy**

I'm now organizing the application's components. I've broken down `Layout` to include `Sidebar`, `ChatView`, `ImageGeneratorView`, `MessageBubble`, `Settings`, `About`, and `Privacy` components.  I'm also paying close attention to the correct Gemini API syntax and ensuring the appropriate model versions are used for different tasks. Plus, I am making sure the prompts incorporate the desired image style.

import React from 'react'; export const Privacy: React.FC = () => { return (

Privacy Policy

Our Commitment

At OursGPT, your privacy is our top priority. We believe that your digital conversations and creations should remain under your control.

Data Storage

All message history, chat threads, and generated images are stored using your browser's localStorage. This data never touches our permanent databases. It stays on your device and is cleared only if you choose to clear your browser cache or use the "Clear Data" feature in settings.

AI Processing

When you send a message or request an image, your prompt and any attached visuals are processed by the Google Gemini API to generate a response. Please refer to Google's Privacy Policy for more information on how they handle API requests.

Third-Party Services

We use standard web services to provide basic functionality:

  • Google Gemini API: For core AI reasoning and generation capabilities.
  • Tailwind CSS CDN: For styling our modern interface.
  • Lucide Icons: For visual navigation elements.

Last Updated: May 2024. For questions, contact privacy@oursgpt.ai

); };

IMPORTANT FORMATTING RULES:

Always respond using Markdown formatting.

Use **double asterisks** for bold text and ensure it is rendered properly.

Use bullet points, numbered lists, headings, and bold keywords when helpful.

Never output plain text when emphasis is needed‚Äîalways use Markdown.

Do NOT escape or remove Markdown symbols (**, *, #, -).

Output must be Markdown-compatible and ready for direct rendering in a web UI.

üß™ Extra Safety Prompt (Highly Recommended)

Add this too if your AI sometimes ignores formatting:

If bold or formatted text does not render, rewrite the response using proper Markdown until formatting is visible.

‚öôÔ∏è Frontend Tip (VERY IMPORTANT)

If bold still doesn‚Äôt show, the problem is not AI, it‚Äôs your UI.

Make sure:

You are rendering AI output using:

innerHTML with a Markdown parser (like marked.js)

OR React Markdown (react-markdown)

NOT using textContent

Example (JS):

element.innerHTML = marked.parse(aiResponse);

**Improving Markdown Handling**

I'm currently focused on how to handle Markdown formatting better within the `MessageBubble.tsx` component.  It's currently just a `div` with `whitespace-pre-wrap`, and that's not cutting it. I'm thinking about how to render more complex Markdown elements effectively. I need to make sure the output is clean and easy to read. I'm aiming for something that is both visually appealing and accurately represents the original Markdown.


**Incorporating Markdown Parsing**

I've decided to integrate `marked` for Markdown rendering. I'll need to update `index.html` to include the library via importmap, and then modify `MessageBubble.tsx` to utilize `marked` to convert Markdown content into HTML. My plan also includes adding some basic CSS rules to `index.html` to style the rendered Markdown elements like bold text, italics, and lists, as Tailwind's preflight resets some default styles. I'm focusing on ensuring the Markdown looks good within the chat bubbles.


**Refining Markdown Display**

I'm now zeroing in on the finer points of Markdown rendering in the chat bubbles. The goal is clear, readable text. I've added CSS to handle bold and bullet points.  I've also made sure the user's side has white text for readability.  I'm making sure to implement their extensive instructions for the Markdown to look great.


**Implementing Markdown Parsing**

I'm now integrating `marked` more deeply into the pipeline. I'm focusing on ensuring `geminiService.ts` guides the AI to use Markdown effectively in its responses. The recent focus has been on parsing `message.content` using `marked` within the `.tsx` component. The prompt highlights a need to render AI output using `innerHTML` and a Markdown parser to improve the UI display.

payload.text: can you fix dark mode and light mode error

**Addressing the Theme Issue**

I'm currently focused on the `index.html` file, examining the dual style definitions for light and dark modes. Specifically, I'm analyzing the classes applied, like `bg-gray-50 dark:bg-zinc-900`, to understand how the theme switching is intended to function at the root level. My goal is to pinpoint the source of the "dark mode and light mode error" by understanding this foundation.


**Examining Theme Interactions**

I'm now carefully examining the interactions between components.  Specifically, I'm tracing the theme state's journey from `App.tsx` (where it's managed and persisted) to `Settings.tsx` (where the toggle is located) and finally to `Layout.tsx` (where it is used). I'm focusing on potential inconsistencies, such as how the classes within each React component interact with `document.documentElement`'s class list and any conflicts between these classes. I will verify that the Tailwind `dark:` prefix is correctly cascading. I also need to make sure the toggle is properly updating the `isDarkMode` state.


**Uncovering the Cause**

I'm now zeroing in on a potential culprit. While the JavaScript seems sound, a quick scan of the `index.html` file reveals a discrepancy. The `<body>` tag has default light mode classes, which could cause a flash of light mode on initial load before the JavaScript takes over. I suspect this might be the source of the reported issue.


**Identifying Root Causes**

I've been re-examining the `index.html` file, specifically the `<body>` tag, and the JavaScript logic in `App.tsx`. The default light mode classes combined with the transitions on the body are a clear area of concern for an initial flash of light mode. My attention has turned to ensuring the root element's class list is properly managed. The `dark` class added in `App.tsx` could be interfering with initial rendering. Furthermore, I'll review any hardcoded colors in `sidebar` or `header` components that might cause visual conflicts across theme states.


**Pinpointing the Culprit**

I've been meticulously reviewing the code again, focusing on the potential issue with components not correctly using the `dark:` prefix. I see a promising lead: the hardcoded colors in the `.markdown-content` CSS within `index.html`. While the `.dark` class should correctly override these styles, I'm now verifying if any conflicting styles are being applied elsewhere, especially in the `Sidebar`, `Layout`, and `Settings` components. I've re-examined the code in these files to ensure the theme class, `dark:`, is properly applied. I am confident I have the root cause now!


**Rectifying Theme Strategy**

I've discovered the root cause! The Tailwind CDN's default `media` strategy for dark mode is the issue. My app uses a class-based approach. The missing crucial configuration, `tailwind.config = { darkMode: 'class' }`, within the `index.html` <script> tag,  prevents Tailwind from recognizing the class applied by my toggle. This explains the discrepancy, as the system preference is overriding my theme change. With this fix, everything should work as intended.


**Finalizing the Fix**

I've implemented the `tailwind.config = { darkMode: 'class' }` fix, which has resolved the primary theme switching issue. Also, I've standardized the background colors for consistency and added a script to `index.html` to instantly apply the chosen theme, eliminating the flash. Now, the dark and light modes transition seamlessly, and the color swap occurs without flickering, ensuring that all components consistently display the correct theme. I'm pleased with the resolution!

To fix the dark and light mode issue, I need to configure the Tailwind CDN to use the `class` strategy instead of the default `media` strategy. Without this configuration, Tailwind ignores the `.dark` class on the `<html>` element and only responds to the system preference. I will also add a small script to the `<head>` to prevent the "flash" of light mode on page load.

### Technical Updates:
1.  **Tailwind Configuration**: Added `tailwind.config = { darkMode: 'class' }` to the `index.html`.
2.  **Flash Prevention**: Added an inline script in the `<head>` to check `localStorage` and apply the `dark` class before the body renders.
3.  **UI Consistency**: Refined background colors in `Layout.tsx` and `Sidebar.tsx` to ensure a cohesive look in both modes.

entries.description: Add Tailwind dark mode configuration and theme flash prevention script.
Refine background and border colors for better dark mode support.
Update ChatView background and input area styling for better theme contrast.

**Pinpointing the Blank Screen**

I've been analyzing the blank screen issue. The `index.html` file correctly sets up the root div, and `index.tsx` attempts to mount to it using `ReactDOM.createRoot`. However, the black screen in the screenshot suggests a deeper problem. I'm suspecting the rendering process is failing, or perhaps the root element is hidden, but I must investigate further.


**Examining Importmap Impact**

I'm now focusing on the importmap and potential loading failures, particularly with `lucide-react`. The black screen points to a possible unmount or crash, potentially due to the `dark` theme class conflicting with the `body`'s background in `index.html`. `index.tsx` is importing `App` and using `ReactDOM.createRoot` as expected.


**Discovering Missing Link**

I've hit a major snag! The deployed site URL and the blank screen hint at a configuration issue, and I've circled back. Analyzing the screenshot and code, I noticed something critical in `index.html`. There's no script tag importing `index.tsx`, despite the setup description implying an auto-import via ES6 modules. That's a classic reason for a blank screen and seems to be a root cause. This missing link throws everything off.


**Analyzing Environment Setup**

I'm now diving deeper into the environment setup. While the initial instinct pointed to a missing `<script>` tag, the prompt's description about automated importing suggests that's not the issue. I'm scrutinizing `index.html` again, focusing on the `body`'s background color. If React fails to render, the `body`'s default color will show. I'm also re-evaluating the `lucide-react` import from `esm.sh` to ensure it's compatible with React, particularly the import paths.


**Correcting the Importmap**

I've zeroed in on the importmap's crucial missing entry: `"react-dom/client": "https://esm.sh/react-dom@^19.2.3/client"`. This oversight in the `importmap` is a significant red flag, as `index.tsx` relies on `react-dom/client` for rendering. Addressing the `importmap` will resolve the black screen as the root cause. Further, the background class issue and deployment environment differences are currently less important. Let's fix the code!


**Diagnosing Rendering Failure**

I'm now revisiting the rendering process after an evaluation of multiple factors. While the `importmap` is updated with `"react-dom/client"`, I'm double-checking `App.tsx` and related imports for any errors. The `importmap`'s coverage of only external libraries implies that relative imports should work correctly in this environment, with the directory acting as the root. I've also re-examined `index.html`, noting the presence of the `tailwind.config`, theme flash script, and `importmap`. Based on the "can't see the screen" feedback and the black screenshot, my analysis suggests that the `dark` class is being added correctly, but the React app isn't rendering. The `react-dom/client` import in `index.tsx` probably fails because it's still missing from the `importmap`.


**Validating the Importmap**

I believe the importmap is set up correctly for `react-dom/client`, but I will double-check. I'm focusing on validating that the import paths for `react`, `react-dom/client`, and `lucide-react` are all functioning correctly within the specified configuration. I also plan to cross-reference the importmap with the code to ensure there are no inconsistencies that would cause rendering to fail. I want to make sure I haven't missed any essential imports or incorrectly configured dependencies.


**Addressing Deployment Differences**

I'm now investigating deployment differences, with a focus on Vercel's behavior. I've re-examined the project setup and realized that Vercel might not handle the automatic ES6 module import as assumed. The missing `<script type="module" src="index.tsx"></script>` tag in `index.html` is a key indicator of a deployment-related issue. This tag is critical for loading and executing `index.tsx`, especially in a Vercel environment.


**Resolving App Initialization**

I'm now revisiting `App.tsx` and `ImageGeneratorView.tsx` and suspect a crash during app initialization, particularly when parsing `localStorage`. The current initializer for `useState` in `App.tsx` lacks a `try-catch` block, making it prone to errors if `localStorage` contains invalid JSON. I'll add a `try-catch` to safely parse the potentially corrupted data, preventing the application from crashing on startup. This should resolve the black screen as the root cause. This improvement will be propagated to `ImageGeneratorView.tsx` as well.


**Adjusting HTML Structure**

I'm making a critical adjustment to `index.html`. It has the `overflow-hidden` style, making the fully black screen very likely to be a rendering problem and not just a loading issue. I'll focus on the rendering process and content loading and prioritize debugging any element that uses the dark theme. The current background color perfectly matches the `bg-zinc-950` in the screenshot, so I can start by confirming that `index.tsx` is being executed.

I will fix the blank screen issue by making the following improvements:

1.  **Robust Data Initialization**: Add `try-catch` blocks to all `localStorage.getItem` initializers in `App.tsx` and `ImageGeneratorView.tsx`. This prevents the app from crashing if local storage contains invalid JSON (a common cause of white/black screens in web apps).
2.  **Import Map Optimization**: Update the `importmap` in `index.html` to explicitly include `react-dom/client` and ensure proper ESM compatibility for all libraries.
3.  **UI Resilience**: Remove `overflow-hidden` from the `body` during initialization to ensure that if a fallback or error occurs, it is at least visible or scrollable, though we'll maintain the layout's integrity within the React app.
4.  **Role Sequence Verification**: Re-verify the `geminiService` logic to ensure no empty messages or invalid role sequences are sent to the API.

Our Commitment

At OursGPT, your privacy is our top priority. We believe that your digital conversations and creations should remain under your control.

Data Storage
